The benefit of incorporating a neat supervisor goes beyond simple 
manipula=
tion of parameters. To maximize the benefits associated with 
those demonst=
rated in the FSNEAT paper, requires that 
multiple "Initial Populations" be=
 evaluated to identify the most 
beneficial portion of the input feature sp=
ace, which also represents 
the most effective expenditure of computational=
 resources. The below 
sample problem demonstrates the effect of effectivel=
y varying the 
population in a non-linear fashion verses generations of evo=
lution, 
while keeping the parameters constant. It is likely that the 
para=
meters can be advantageously manipulated to accelerate this 
process. While=
 computational time is not recorded, the associated CPU 
time corresponding=
 to increasing number of generations is profoundly 
higher, even for the co=
nstant product of (# Initial Populations)x(# 
Generations of Evolution), wh=
ich is just another way of saying that 
the more complex genomes evolved wi=
th increasing number of 
generations of evolution take disproportionately l=
onger to evaluate.


Type Problem: Data Representation

# Inputs =3D (3) + =
(1) Bias
# Outputs =3D (1)
# Samples =3D (4)
Parameters =3D Held Constant, =
same as "pole2_markov.ne"

Minimal Starter Gene w/ only (1) connection from=
 Bias to Output

"A" =3D # Initial Populations
"B" =3D # Generations
"C" =
=3D Average Overall Highest Fitness (i.e. across all Initial 
Populations)
=
"D" =3D Maximum Overall Highest Fitness (i.e. across all Initial 
Populatio=
ns)
"E" =3D Minimum Overall Highest Fitness (i.e. across all Initial 
Popul=
ations)
